item.title: Hashtag the World | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is the moral dissonance of Ubisoft's Watch Dogs 2, looking at how it goes to great lengths to reference pressing contemporary issues but ultimately misses an opportunity to say much of substance about them.

item.title: Freedom of Choice | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is interactive narrative, looking at Telltale's various "choose your own adventure" style games and positing that controlling the narrative is not the highest expression of interactivity.

item.title: A Tale of Two Calamities | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is a parallel reading of Bastion and Transistor, unpacking the similar plot elements that are used to different effects by contrasting aesthetics and tones.

item.title: Cheap As Free | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is the economics of "free to play" games and how design considerations around pricing models impacts the experience, with examples from games like Clash of Clans and Fire Emblem: Heroes.

item.title: Not With a Bang but a Winter | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is the destruction and rebirth in apocalyptic media, with examples from Fallout and The Long Dark.

item.title: Slaying Dragons | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is the power of vulnerability as demonstrated by Numinous Games' That Dragon, Cancer.

item.title: Holding Out for a Hero | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is the lack of meaningful weight to the "simulated heroism" of many modern games, especially World of Warcraft. A counter-example is examined in Metro: 2033.

item.title: Play As You Like | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is the use of theatrical motif in Final Fantasy IX as it relates to playfulness in the sense used by Ian Bogost in his book Play Anything.

item.title: Gotta Glitch 'Em All | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is the speedrun, specifically glitch-based approaches, as an artful application of play to explore titles more fully.

item.title: Reality, Augmented | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is Augmented and Alternate Reality gaming, examining how Niantic's Ingress aligns its many facets to enhance the experience.

item.title: Free to be Useless | FPS
item.description: Response to Luca Morini's "Play as the Bulwark of Uselessness", published at First Person Scholar.

item.title: The Content Factory | Haywire Magazine
item.description: Monthly column examining videogames as "play." This month's topic is relationship between the commodification of games and working conditions in the game industry.
